title: Homeowner 'overcharged' so much by Npower he's now £20,000 in CREDIT - Mirror Online

News Homeowner 'overcharged' so much by Npower he's now £20,000 in CREDIT Two-and-a-half years ago David Redfern's bills rocketed from £60 a month to nearer £500 for no reason he could fathom - and he's had to keep paying all this time while locked in dispute Share David had to keep paying his bill as he feared being cut off - despite it rocketing (Photo: Nottingham Post / SWNS.com) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! A homeowner claims he has been 'overcharged' so much by Npower that he is now £20,000 in CREDIT. 
Two-and-a-half years ago David Redfern's energy bills for his three-bedroom house rocketed from £60 a month to nearer £500 for no reason he could fathom. 
All that time he's been locked in dispute with the utilities firm - and in the meantime he has had to keep paying his bills, fearing he would be cut off. 
Since he got his meter replaced in November, his gas and electricity has subsequently shrunk by more than £430 a month - from an enormous £478.89 to more manageable £48. 
According to calculations, David should now not have to pay another bill for the next 33 years. 
But he has been stressed out all this time trying to cope with the huge bills - and trying to use less power. David Redfern did everything he could to cut his electricity usage (Photo: Nottingham Post / SWNS.com) 
The online marketing expert told the Nottingham Post how he has been constantly fighting the utilities firm - but carried on paying the huge monthly amount in the meantime. 
The problem was finally solved in November, when Npower agreed to change the meter at his home in Newthorpe, Notts. 
David has now spoken out about how the enormous bills affected his and his partner's living habits - as he wants to try and warn others who have been wrongly charged. 
He explained: "We have been paying them a lot of money for a long time now for a three-bedroom house. 
"It's a crazy amount of money, we are now that much in credit. 
"Our electricity bill just went up dramatically. Npower says it is investigating (Photo: PA) 
"I assumed it was because we had a hot tub, or maybe that just electricity prices are rising. 
"I even went to the trouble of replacing every single lightbulb and light with LED. 
"We hardly use any electricity - we are extremely cautious. But with these bills, it was like we had a fairground running. 
"My business doesn't even use as much as this. 
"I used the washing machine once a day, but thought that was being excessive. 
"I've been arguing with Npower for years and years. 
"I just knew I shouldn't be using this much, even when I bought consumption meters. 
"But I knew I had to pay it. The Npower bill reduced when his meter was changed (Photo: PA) 
"I don't think it's fair on all these other people who are probably affected. 
"I have been in the fortunate position where I've actually managed to pay it, but a lot of other people wouldn't have been in that position and could have been cut off. 
"There are probably other customers around the UK who have had this problem. 
"People should really look into this and not just accept it. 
"We need to help all these people who are potentially struggling. 
"It's detrimental to people's lifestyles." 
A tweet David shared on his seo77 Twitter account, expressing his anger at the over-charge, has been retweeted more than 4,000 times. 
David said once he successfully got Npower to change his meter over, he saw his bills drop to £60. 
He said the stress of paying the massive bills had taken its toll, and he had to throw himself into his business to ensure he could keep up the payments. Read More British Gas extends energy price freeze as bills hike for 2 million households - but experts warn you're STILL losing £170 a year 
According to ukpower.co.uk , the website recommended by gas and electricity regulator Ofgem, the average monthly bill for a medium-sized house is £89, based on gas usage of 12,500kWh and an electricity usage of 3,100kWh. 
An Npower spokeswoman said they could not comment on how the charge had come about, but added that David's account was on hold while the matter was being looked into. Read More 
The firm is also planning on sending a home energy expert to David's home to check his energy use and meter. 
The spokeswoman said: "We're sorry to hear about this confusion. 
"We know that the online account details are incorrect and these are now being amended. 
"We're keen to find out why Mr Redfern's energy use is so high so we're popping round to see what we can do to try to help him reduce this." 
- Ofgem recommends that David and customers in a similar position contact Citizen's Advice Bureau's consumer helpline on 03454 04 05 06 (Textphone: 18001 03454 04 05 06) or Ofgem's consumer affairs team on 020 7901 7295 or email . Like us on Facebook
